repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
- Many other ftplugin have defined 'omnifunc', but the Lua one doesn't define one, even though there is `vim.lua_omnifunc()`
- Users may want "stupid" completion if they break their config and have to fix it with `nvim --clean`

Solution:
Set 'omnifunc' to 'v:lua.vim.lua_omnifunc' in ftplugin/lua.lua

TODO
- [x] insert.txt (`:h ft-lua-omni`)
- [x] news.txt (Under new features -> defaults -> options)

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -69,6 +69,7 @@ Defaults                                            *defaults* *nvim-defaults*
 - 'mouse' defaults to "nvi", see |default-mouse| for details
 - 'mousemodel' defaults to "popup_setpos"
 - 'nrformats' defaults to "bin,hex"
+- 'omnifunc'. The Lua ftplugin sets it to "v:lua.vim.lua_omnifunc"

comment_data.body: So where should that senctence live?

+|vim.lua_omnifunc()|.

comment_regular_data.body: You mean this https://github.com/vim/vim/pull/16655? I don't think it has any relation with this PR though, I think that PR is more related to this issue https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32490 (since ~~there would be~~ I will add another `includeexpr` for Nvim-favored Lua in another PR). I really want to know your opinion on that issue

That's right, ignore my comments (sorry about that)! 

Regarding includexpr, I agree that this should first go to Vim (and I can't help you there; the less overt Neovim presence, the smoother things will go). 

Also pinging @bfredl as the one who added the Lua omnifunc (for a different purpose!)

Note that this breaks the default `vim.lsp.omnifunc` when luals attaches (which personally I find much more useful).

@mfussenegger

Btw, I wonder if features specific to Nvim-favored Lua like this one should be enabled in all Lua files or only though in runtimepath and can be opt-in/opt-out? Because in the future, _maybe_ Vim will make another omnifunc for Lua filetype, then Nvim will has 2 omnifunc for Lua.

Also, I'm planning to send another PR with a Nvim-Lua specific includeexpr (for this issue https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32490), so combined existing one, Nvim will end up with 2 includeexpr for filetype Lua
See comment above. Personally, I don't think it makes sense to build a "language server at home" when luals and emmylua_ls exist and will work for any Lua project.

> Note that this breaks the default `vim.lsp.omnifunc` when luals attaches (which personally I find much more useful).

?? I assumed that would not be the case, because that is obviously not acceptable :)

I need to revert this then.



> Btw, I wonder if features specific to Nvim-favored Lua like this one should be enabled in all Lua files or only though in runtimepath and can be opt-in/opt-out?

Please do whatever keeps the "rules" simple and easy to understand. Avoid special cases.

> ?? I assumed that would not be the case, because that is obviously not acceptable :)

So do I. Because I think Nvim already check if `is_empty_or_default(bufnr, 'omnifunc')` before `vim.bo[bufnr].omnifunc = 'v:lua.vim.lsp.omnifunc'` https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/f398e3a61abbf802b49867d2f533be1b0725c0d7/runtime/lua/vim/lsp.lua#L732
Yes, but the LSP omnifunc is only set on attach, so later. This simply won't work here.

> Yes, but the LSP omnifunc is only set on attach, so later. This simply won't work here.

I don't think that is relevant. I have tried testing with another option that is `'commentstring'` and `'omnifunc'` in C filetype. A notable difference between these 2 options is that `'cms'` is last set in [c.lua](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/f398e3a61abbf802b49867d2f533be1b0725c0d7/runtime/ftplugin/c.lua), while `'omnifunc'` is only set once in [c.vim](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/f398e3a61abbf802b49867d2f533be1b0725c0d7/runtime/ftplugin/c.vim)

This is what I did
1. Add the following to `repro.lua`
```lua
---@see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/6bc79790449f8bbf238b740bf6eb33cea88e4295/runtime/lua/vim/lsp.lua#L655
function IsEmptyOrDefault(bufnr, option)
	if vim.bo[bufnr][option] == '' then
		return true
	end

	local info = vim.api.nvim_get_option_info2(option, { buf = bufnr })
	---@param e vim.fn.getscriptinfo.ret
	local scriptinfo = vim.tbl_filter(function(e)
		return e.sid == info.last_set_sid
	end, vim.fn.getscriptinfo())

	if #scriptinfo ~= 1 then
		return false
	end

	return vim.startswith(scriptinfo[1].name, vim.fn.expand('$VIMRUNTIME'))
end
```
2.  `$ nvim test.c --clean -u repro.lua`
3. `:=IsEmptyOrDefault(0, 'omnifunc')  " return true`
4. `:=IsEmptyOrDefault(0, 'commentstring') " return false`
So `'commentstring'` is not default even in clean mode?
6. `:=vim.api.nvim_get_option_info2('omnifunc', { buf = 0 }).last_set_sid  " return 23`
7. `:=vim.api.nvim_get_option_info2('commentstring', {buf = 0}).last_set_sid  " return -8`
This is really strange because Nvim is run in clean mode. Also is negative SID possible?
8. To be more sure, I run `:scriptnames` and realize that the file `$VIMRUNTIME/ftplugin/c.lua` has SID 24 (which seems normal, as it is loaded right after `$VIMRUNTIME/ftplugin/c.vim`). So why is result of step 6 above a negative number?

9.
```vim
:setl commentstring=foo%s
:=vim.api.nvim_get_option_info2('commentstring', {buf = 0}).last_set_sid  " return 0
:lua vim.cmd('setl commentstring=bar%s')
:=vim.api.nvim_get_option_info2('commentstring', {buf = 0}).last_set_sid  " return -8
```

So whenever I set option in Lua, no matter if in a script file or in cmdline, no matter if I use Nvim API directly or calling Vimscript from Lua, `last_set_sid` is always -8.
Given that https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32598 has been resolved, can this PR be added again?
Sure, if there is a way to avoid interfering with the LSP default.

title: feat(ftplugin): set 'omnifunc' of Lua to 'v:lua.vim.lua_omnifunc'
